lg.l: Where stately Clutha’s arms enfold
Her island Inch Clutha. Inch Clutha is an island in the Clutha River/Mata-Au, in the South Island of New Zealand. round, is to be seen
A tree stump marvellous to behold—
So vast in girth, that what had been
A tree so mighty one might well
Deplore the cause there was to fell.
But anger soon with sorrow blends
When told what sent its sentence forth,
That had no place in paltry ends
Connected with its market worth,
(That wields o’er men such potent law),
And doomed it to the Woodman’s saw.
A craven vile, with nature mean,
Whose charge the workmen were, to vent
Against its owner his poor spleen,
Had the tree felled for this intent;
His mean soul pleased when on the ground
He heard its thund’ring shock resound.
But for that ill-timed prank, I wot
Its top umbrageous, tow’ring vast,
Might yet on high long proudly float,
And on the ground its shadow cast;
With zealous care guarded from harm
As some prized object on the farm.
Yet it was once a tree of fame,
When high it towered o’er the glade;
And travellers from a distance came,
And its huge form in awe surveyed,
As like some Anakim Anakim. A race of giants mentioned in the Bible (e.g. Deuteronomy 1:28). it stood
The undoubted monarch of the wood.
Ere yet the ruthless Pakeha Pakeha. Pākehā are settlers of British or European descent.
Appeared with desolating axe,
And tangled brakes, where erst some pah Pah. A pā is a Māori fortified settlement.
Was haply screened ‘mid scrub and flax,
With echoing strokes then quickly cleared,
Its towering form there long was reared.
Around its top, an object marked,
Ten thousand storms had haply raved
With howling blasts, and lightnings forked,
Yet still unscathed had all been braved;
Till treach’rous act from a mean foe
Its mighty form at length laid low.
And of the tree late in that place,
Whose wealth of timber gave such cause
For wonder, now is found no trace;
The stump but shows what once it was,
And thistles now suffice to hide
What lately was the forest’s pride.
Like it the man, who once in pride
His name “writ large” upon the earth,
With wealth and substance spreading wide,
And yet of useful works was dearth—
And that he lived is now but known
Through some rich monumental stone.
